title: 113_s801
content: The "Prairie Protection Act of 2013" may be cited as such. The Act addresses crop production on native sod. The "Prairie Protection Act of 2013" addresses crop production on native sod by amending the Federal Crop Insurance Act to include provisions related to crop insurance premium subsidies, benefits under other agricultural acts, and payments under the Food Security Act of 1985. The "Prairie Protection Act of 2013" amends the Federal Crop Insurance Act to provide crop insurance premium subsidies and benefits for producers planting on native sod acreage. During the first 4 crop years, 65% of the transitional yield applies with a reduced premium subsidy of 50 percentage points. The Prairie Protection Act of 2013 prohibits yield substitution for native sod acreage and amends the Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance program to include benefits and crop insurance premium subsidies for producers on such acreage. The Prairie Protection Act of 2013 prohibits yield substitution for native sod acreage and includes benefits and crop insurance premium subsidies for producers on such acreage. The Act also addresses administration during the first 4 crop years of planting on native sod acreage. The Prairie Protection Act of 2013 prohibits yield substitution for native sod acreage and reduces crop insurance premium subsidies for producers on such acreage. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to submit a cropland report within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Prairie Protection Act of 2013 mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to provide annual reports on cropland acreage changes in each county and state starting from 2000. The reports are to be submitted to the relevant committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The report to the Senate committee includes cropland acreage, changes from the previous year, and conversion of native sod to cropland or other uses in each county and State.
